chunk_summary: Antimicrobial stewardship in typhoid fever focuses on managing resistance, optimizing empiric therapy, and preserving drug efficacy through culture-guided treatment and de-escalation strategies.
learning_objectives: Understand the role of antimicrobial stewardship in managing typhoid and enteric fever in India.
Identify resistance patterns and appropriate empiric therapy adjustments for children with typhoid fever.
Learn the importance of culture-guided therapy and de-escalation to narrow-spectrum agents.
Recognize the need to avoid unnecessary treatment of non-typhoidal fevers.
key_facts: Resistance should be suspected if no clinical improvement occurs by day 5–7 despite appropriate therapy.
Fluoroquinolone resistance is common; empiric fluoroquinolones are generally avoided in children.
Azithromycin is preferred for ceftriaxone-reduced susceptibility in clinically stable children.
Carbapenems like meropenem (40 mg/kg every 8 hours) are reserved for severe or extensively drug-resistant typhoid.
De-escalation to the narrowest effective oral agent is recommended once culture results confirm susceptibility.
Full-course completion is essential to reduce relapse and transmission.
reference_quote: Fluoroquinolone resistance and reduced susceptibility are common, so empiric fluoroquinolones are generally avoided in children. (Source: National Treatment Guidelines for Antimicrobial Use in Infectious Diseases, India)
document_key_topics: Stewardship strategies to preserve drug efficacy
